Your stock exchange is a big supermarket of companies, and you're going to be buying stocks. What do you want to have happen? You want those stocks to go down, way down. You will make better buys then. Later on, 20 or 30 years from now, when you're in a period when you're dissaving, or when your heirs are dissaving for you—you're gone—then you may care about higher prices.

There's a chapter eight in Ben Graham's *The Intelligent Investor* about the attitude toward stock market fluctuations, and then the chapter 20 on the margin of safety. Those are the two most important essays ever written on investing, as far as I'm concerned. When I read chapter eight when I was 19, I figured out what I just said. It's obvious. I didn't figure it out myself; it was explained to me. I probably would have gone another hundred years and still thought it was good when my stocks were going up.

We want things to go down. But I have no idea what the stock market's going to do. I never do, never will. It's not something that I think about at all. When it goes down, I look harder at what I might buy that day, because I know there's more likely to be some merchandise there that I can use my money effectively in.


### Closing Reflections: The Ovarian Lottery and Designing a Just World

**Moderator:**  
Okay Warren, we'll take one more question from the audience.

**Warren Buffett:**  
Okay, I'll let you pick who gets it, then you can be the guy.

**Audience Member:**  
If you may again study your life again, then what would you like to do to have a happier life?

**Warren Buffett:**

The question is what would I do if I were going to live over again and have a happier life. The only thing I might do is select a gene pool where people live to be 120 or something. I've been extraordinarily lucky.

I use this example. Let's assume it was 24 hours before you were born and a genie came to you and he said, "Herb, you look very promising, and I've got a big problem. I've got to design the world in which you're going to live." Then he says, "I've decided, the hell with it, it's too tough. You design it. So you've got 24 hours. You figure out what the social rules should be, the economic rules, the governmental rules, and you're going to live under those, and your kids are going to live under them, and their kids are going to live under them."

You say, "I can design anything?" And the genie says, "Yeah, you can do it." And you say, "Well, there must be a catch." He says, "Well, there is a catch. You don't know whether you're going to be born black or white, rich or poor, male or female, infirm or able-bodied, bright or not so bright. All you know is you're going to take one ball out of a barrel that's got 5.8 billion balls in it. You're going to participate in what I call the ovarian lottery. You're going to get one ball out of there, and that is the most important thing that's ever going to happen to you in your life, because that is going to control whether you're born here or in Afghanistan, whether you're born with an IQ of 130 or an IQ of 70. It's going to determine a whole lot. You're going to go out in the world and you're going to have that ball."

Now, what kind of a world do you want to design? I think that's a good way to look at social questions, because not knowing which ball you're going to get, you're going to want a system that produces lots of goods and services, because you're going to want people on balance to live well. You're going to want one that produces more and more so your kids live better than you do and your grandchildren live better than the kids. But you're also going to want a system that, if it does produce lots of goods and services, does not leave behind a person that accidentally got the wrong ball and is not well wired for this particular system.

I'm ideally wired for the system I fell into here. I came out and I got something that enables me to allocate capital. There's nothing so wonderful about that. If all of us were stranded on a desert island—we all landed there and we were never going to get off of it—the most valuable person would be the one that could raise the most rice over time. I could say, "I'm going to allocate capital," and you'd say, "How about paying me?" and you wouldn't get very excited about that. So I am in the right place.

Gates says if I'd been born a few million years ago I'd have been some animal's lunch. He says, "You can't run very fast, you can't climb trees, you can't do anything. You'd just have been chewed up on the first day." He says, "You're lucky you were born today." And I am.

One question you can ask yourself, incidentally, is: here is this barrel with 5.8 billion balls—everybody in the world. If you could put your ball back and then they took out, at random, a hundred other balls and you had to pick one of those, would you put your ball back in? Now, of those hundred balls that you're going to get out, roughly five of them will be American, so there are 95 versus five. You're only going to have five balls if you want to be in this country. Half of them are going to be women, half of them are going to be men. I'll let you decide how you vote on that one. Half of them are going to be below-average intelligence, half are going to be above.

Do you want to put your ball back? Most of you, I think, would not want to put that ball back to get a hundred. What you're saying is, "I'm in the luckiest 1% of the world right now, sitting in this room. I'm in the top 1% of the world." That's the way I feel. I've been lucky to be born where I was, because it was 50 to 1 against me being in the United States when I was born. Lucky with parents, lucky with all kinds of things. Then lucky to be wired in a way that in a market economy pays off like crazy for me. It doesn't pay off for somebody who's absolutely as good a citizen as I am—leading Boy Scout troops, teaching Sunday school, raising fine families—but just doesn't happen to be wired in the same way I am.

So I've been extremely lucky. I'd like to be lucky again. If I'm lucky, then the way to do it is to play out that game and do something you enjoy all your life and be associated with people you like. I only work with people I like. If I could make a hundred million by buying a business with some guy that caused my stomach to churn, I'd say no, because I'd say that's just like marrying for money, which probably isn't a very good idea in any circumstances, but if you're already rich it's crazy. I'm not going to marry for money.

So I would do almost exactly what I've done—except I don't think I would have bought the U.S. Air.

Thanks.

parts:
This is a *very* Buffett-style talk: half moral philosophy and life advice, half investing heuristics, delivered with jokes, vivid metaphors, and selective numbers. As a speech to MBA students it’s effective. As a *general theory of investing and markets*, it’s a mix of genuinely deep principles and oversimplifications that can mislead if taken literally.

Below is an honest critique, section by section.

---

## What the speech is trying to do (and why it works)

He’s not giving a lecture in finance; he’s shaping a *mental model* for decision-making:

- **Character first** (integrity → long-run trust and opportunity set).
- **Avoid ruin** (leverage + tail risk can erase decades of skill).
- **Stay in your circle of competence** (know what you know).
- **Prefer compounding machines** (durable advantages + time).
- **Ignore noise** (especially macro forecasts and Wall Street stimulation).
- **Take the “veil of ignorance” seriously** (“ovarian lottery” → design a society you’d accept not knowing your starting position).

That package is persuasive because it’s internally coherent, emotionally resonant, and delivered in concrete images (moats, cigar butts, Russian roulette, fondling Berkshire certificates).

The danger is that coherence + charisma can make the claims feel more universal than they really are.

---

## 1) “Integrity, intelligence, energy” + the “buy 10% of a classmate” game

**What’s strong**
- The “buy 10% / short 10%” thought experiment is *excellent pedagogy*. It forces people to admit they don’t actually prize IQ and hustle alone; they prize *trustworthiness, generosity, credit-giving, reliability*—the social capital that compounds.
- He makes a good point about **habit formation**: virtues and vices are path-dependent; it’s easier to steer early.

**What’s weak / incomplete**
- It’s a bit *clean-room moral psychology*. Many career outcomes are shaped by structural constraints, incentives, and institutional culture. Integrity isn’t just a personal choice; it can be punished in some environments unless governance and incentives support it.
- He implies “you can just choose these traits,” which is partly true for behavior, but less true for temperament, mental health, trauma, or chronic stress. The core message stands, but the “anyone can” framing is too frictionless.

---

## 2) Japan and “borrow at 1% for 10 years”

**What’s strong**
- He reduces the problem to a simple hurdle rate: if capital costs ~1%, you only need opportunities that reliably clear it *without hidden risks*. That’s a disciplined way to think.
- He focuses on **return on equity (ROE)** (how efficiently a firm turns shareholder capital into profit), which matters a lot in long-term compounding.

**What’s weak / incomplete**
- He treats Japan’s low ROE as almost destiny (“culture might change”). That’s plausible, but it’s also a classic trap: **macro/structural regimes do change** (governance reforms, buybacks, payout norms, competition policy). A low-ROE environment can still produce bargains if prices reflect pessimism.
- He also frames “currency risk” as something to avoid, but in practice you can hedge (at a cost) and you can diversify exposures. He’s selling a preference as a principle.

---

## 3) Long-Term Capital Management (LTCM): “smart people did dumb things”

He’s making a *risk-of-ruin* argument: don’t trade “something you need” for a marginal upside you don’t need.

**What’s strong**
- The core lesson is real: **leverage turns small model error into existential risk**.
- His Russian roulette analogy is basically an informal expected-utility argument where “utility of survival” is non-linear and bankruptcy is catastrophic.
- His best line here is: *“to make money they didn’t have and didn’t need, they risked what they did have and did need.”* That’s a good heuristic for personal finance and for institutional risk-taking.

**Where he overreaches**
- He takes a broad swipe at “mathematics,” “beta,” and “sigmas.”
  - **Beta** (a measure of how a stock covaries with the market) is *not* a measure of bankruptcy risk, so his critique lands **against naive beta-as-risk**.
  - But dismissing quantitative risk methods entirely is too far. The real problem wasn’t “math”; it was **model risk**, **fat tails** (financial returns are not well-described by a stable normal distribution), **liquidity risk**, and **crowded trades** interacting with leverage.
- He implies the moral is “avoid leverage,” but there’s nuance:
  - Some leverage is structurally unavoidable (e.g., insurance float, banks, mortgages).
  - The real principle is **avoid leverage that can force liquidation under stress** (maturity mismatch, margin calls, fragile funding).

**Subtle contradiction**
- He says, “We never basically borrow money,” but Berkshire’s **insurance float** is economically similar to borrowing: other people’s money, invested for Berkshire’s benefit, with obligations attached. It can be *very safe* if underwritten well, but it’s still leverage-like. He downplays that because his version is long-duration and operationally controlled, but it’s not “no leverage.”

## 4) “Moats,” brands, and simplicity (Coke, See’s, Wrigley, Kodak)

**What’s strong**
- “Moat” is a powerful abstraction for durable competitive advantage: cost advantage, brand, switching costs, distribution, network effects, regulation, location, patents, etc.
- He’s excellent on **pricing power**: the difference between “I need promotions to move product” versus “the product sells itself.”
- The “share of mind” framing is insightful. Brand isn’t just awareness; it’s default choice under uncertainty and limited attention.

**Where it can mislead**
- **Moats are often invisible *until they aren’t*.** He acknowledges moats can narrow, but his tone still leans toward “the great ones stay great.” History is less forgiving: consumer behavior shifts, technology shifts, regulation shifts, health norms shift.
- His Kodak example is interesting because it’s a warning about moat erosion—but it also shows the limitation of the whole approach: sometimes the “moat” is sitting on top of a technological discontinuity that destroys the profit pool.
- “Simple business” is a preference, not a proof of safety. Plenty of “simple” businesses get disrupted (retail, newspapers, taxis). Simplicity helps *understanding*; it doesn’t guarantee durability.

**The Coke “no taste memory” claim**
- It’s rhetorically brilliant, but scientifically and behaviorally it’s overstated. People absolutely do develop taste fatigue and shifting preferences, and public health trends matter. The *directional* point—habitual consumption supports volume—is fair; the categorical phrasing is marketing-grade certainty.

---

## 5) Valuation and the qualitative/quantitative split

**What’s strong**
- He emphasizes that valuation is inseparable from *business understanding*.
- His See’s Candy story is a clean illustration of pricing power and capital-light economics.

**What’s weak**
- The “we decide in five minutes” trope is inspirational but dangerous as advice. It works for someone with:
  - decades of pattern recognition,
  - privileged access to information and deal flow,
  - a reputation that changes seller behavior,
  - and the ability to do bespoke transactions.
- For normal investors, “five minutes” becomes an excuse for overconfidence. Most people *think* they’re inside their circle of competence when they’re not.

---

## 6) “Ignore macro forecasts completely”

**What’s strong**
- Macro forecasting is genuinely hard; most forecasts are noise, and acting on them often increases turnover and fees.
- For very long holding periods, business quality usually dominates short-run macro fluctuations.

**What’s incomplete**
- “Macro doesn’t matter” is too absolute. Macro variables (rates, inflation regimes, regulation, geopolitics) can:
  - change discount rates (valuation),
  - change competitive dynamics,
  - change bankruptcy probabilities,
  - and reshape entire industries.
- The better version is: **macro is hard to forecast, so don’t pretend you can**, but still stress-test your holdings for macro-sensitive failure modes (funding costs, demand shocks, currency mismatches).

---

## 7) Diversification: index funds for most; concentration for professionals

**What’s strong**
- His advice for most people—low-cost index funds, low turnover—is excellent.
- He correctly points out that over-diversification can turn skill into “index + fees.”

**What’s overstated**
- “If you really know businesses you shouldn’t own more than six” and “the seventh is a terrible mistake” is rhetorical absolutism.
  - Concentration increases **idiosyncratic risk** (risk specific to one company).
  - Even skilled investors face model error and unknown unknowns.
- A more defensible view: concentrate **only to the extent your edge is real and your downside is survivable**.

---

## 8) Career advice: “take the job you love”

**What’s strong**
- It’s psychologically correct: compounding applies to skills and motivation too. If you love the work, you do more reps, and you get better.
- The résumé/consulting line (“saving up sex for old age”) is memorable and, for many MBAs, probably needed.

**What’s missing**
- This advice assumes you have a safety net (family support, low obligations, good health). Many people must optimize for stability first.
- The more universal version: **optimize early for learning rate and long-run optionality, not short-run prestige**—but sometimes stability is the precondition for that.

## 9) The closing: “ovarian lottery” and designing a just world

This is the most philosophically serious part.

**What’s strong**
- It’s basically John Rawls’ “veil of ignorance” translated into Buffett’s language.
- He acknowledges luck and “being wired for the system” as morally arbitrary, which is unusually candid for an ultra-wealthy capitalist.
- He argues for a system that is both productive **and** doesn’t abandon those who draw a bad lot—an implicit case for some redistribution and strong institutions.

**What’s weak**
- He stops at the parable and avoids specifics—tax policy, education, healthcare, labor power, antitrust, political capture. That’s understandable in a speech, but it makes the conclusion feel like moral sentiment rather than actionable design.
- There’s also a tension: he frames himself as “just lucky,” which is partly true, but it can underplay how wealth also compounds through power, access, and institutional influence.

## The best parts (worth keeping)

- **Avoid ruin**: if you can’t survive tail outcomes, your skill doesn’t matter.
- **Circle of competence**: know what you know; don’t outsource conviction to gossip or charts.
- **Time + great economics** beats cleverness: compounding is king.
- **Most people should index**: low fees, low turnover, own productive capacity.
- **Character compounds**: reputation is a hidden asset that expands your opportunity set.

## The parts to treat as “Buffett rhetoric,” not universal law

- “Macro never matters.”
- “Quant metrics tell you nothing.”
- “Five minutes is enough.”
- “Six stocks is optimal; the seventh is a mistake.”
- “Brand moats are basically permanent.”
- “No taste memory” / overly categorical consumer claims.
